physDesc.p: Two pages typewritten in black ink. Address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page: Mrs. Richard Aldington c/o Miss Winifred Ellerman Carmel Highlands Inn Carmel by the sea Monterey, California. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Since writing a letter to Winifred yesterday, I have had another communication from Ferris Greenslet of the Houghton Mifflin Company. He says that he thinks England is the best place to have the book set up in, and he will be perfectly willing to take a certain number of sheets for sale in America. He thinks you have a larger audience in England still than you have in America, and perhaps that is true. He is going to England in February and he proposes to take the manuscript of the book with him, arranging for a publisher there – I imagine it will be Constable since he is their agent – and arranging to have the sheets brought back here.

If I were you, I should accept this, for I am inclined to believe that this estimate of your popularity in England is correct, and I think Houghton Mifflin are a much better firm for this kind of thing than Holt, whom I mentioned to Winifred in my letter yesterday. I do not think the thing will go to pieces in any way if you leave it in Ferris’s hands and if you give me carte blanche to arrange with him as I would for myself, or, if you prefer, he will communicate with you directly. He was perfectly willing to do so, but I told him to wait before I was afraid to trouble you with business details.

If this matter meets with your approval, I will tell Ferris to go ahead and see what arrangements he can make in England. If you would prefer to try America first, I will send it to Holt, as I proposed to do in my letter to Winifred, but of course, in that case, it will be difficult to go back again to Ferris Greenslet, supposing Holt should refuse. There are other publishers, but I think none as good as Houghton Mifflin or Macmillan. I doubt whether Harcourt, Brace & Howe, who go in very much for the socialist radical books, would care for the book. Knopf is feeling poor at the moment, and I am much averse to trying new upstarts like Thomas Seltzer, and there is simply no hope of the old fogy publishers like Scribner and Harper. My advice would be to leave it in Ferris’s hands and see what he can do. He wants your name on his list, but he is a little afraid to risk entire publication in this country.

Much love, dear Hilda, and I do trust that Monterey will do as much good as it sounds as if it would. Winifred makes it out perfectly delightful, and I wish I were with you dabbling my feet in the ocean and looking at that lovely view which I remember so well. Instead of that, I go to bed on Friday and am cut into little pieces. Let me know what to do about Ferris, and believe me,
